description: Large social cat native to Africa and India.
Large-bodied great ape living in social groups.
A small Amazonian primate that moves by agile leaps through dense understorey and feeds on fruit, insects, and fungi; unlike many callitrichids it typically produces a single infant.
A domesticated two-humped camel adapted to cold, arid climates, used as a pack and riding animal across Central Asia; its thick coat and fat-storing humps help it endure temperature extremes.
A compact domestic goat breed valued for hardiness and milk production; its small size and browsing diet make it well suited to mixed farmland and smallholdings.
A shy, forest-edge antelope of southeastern Africa that browses leaves and fallen fruit; its rich reddish coat provides camouflage in dense undergrowth.
A threatened West African mangabey with a pale nape and long tail, living in social troops in forests and woodland; it is an opportunistic forager eating fruit, seeds, and invertebrates.
A West African guenon with striking facial markings and a white throat ruff; it is an agile canopy-dweller that feeds mainly on fruit but also takes insects and young leaves.
A robust armadillo of southern South America with long guard hairs over its armour; it digs extensive burrows and eats a broad mix of insects, roots, and carrion.
A small, largely nocturnal hippo restricted to West African forests and swamps; it spends daylight hours hidden near water and feeds on leaves, ferns, and fallen fruit at night.
A slow-moving, nocturnal sloth of northern South American rainforests with two claws on each forelimb; it hangs from branches and feeds mainly on leaves, supplemented with fruit.
A black-and-white colobus subspecies from central Kenya, adapted to life high in the canopy; it specialises on leaves using a complex foregut fermentation system and often leaps between trees.
A nocturnal lemur famous for its elongated middle finger, used to tap wood and extract insect larvae; it also eats fruit and seeds, including gnawing into hard shells.
Large herbivorous mammal native to South and Southeast Asia.
The world’s largest lizard, native to a few Indonesian islands.
A small, endangered tamarin from Brazil’s Atlantic Forest with a golden head and dark body; it forages for fruit and insects and relies on tree cavities for sleeping sites.
An endangered Atlantic Forest tamarin with a vivid orange coat and a mane-like ruff; it lives in family groups and feeds on fruit, nectar, and small animals gleaned from bark crevices.
A slender, nocturnal primate of India and Sri Lanka that moves slowly and silently through branches; it feeds on insects and plant exudates and has a strong grip for careful climbing.
A tiny antelope of East African savannas and bushland that often lives in monogamous pairs; it browses leaves and shoots and uses a short, flexible snout to pick food.
A small nocturnal lemur from western Madagascar that feeds on fruit, insects, and gum; it can enter torpor to conserve energy during cool or food-scarce periods.
Europe’s smallest rodent, adapted to grasslands and reedbeds; it builds spherical nests woven from grasses and feeds on seeds, berries, and small invertebrates.
A threatened Malagasy mongoose restricted to western Madagascar; it forages on the ground for insects and small vertebrates and shows distinctive striping along the back.
A small deer native to China and Taiwan with barking alarm calls and short antlers; it browses woodland edges and has expanded its range through introductions in parts of Europe.
A domesticated form of the European polecat kept as a companion animal and historically used for rabbit control; it is a curious, highly flexible carnivore with a strong prey drive.
A diurnal South American coati that forages in bands, using a long, mobile snout to probe leaf litter; it eats fruit, insects, and small vertebrates across forests and savannas.
A critically endangered gibbon from northern Vietnam and Laos; it forms monogamous pairs, travels by brachiation through the canopy, and is known for loud, duetting calls.
A medium-sized wallaby from southeastern Australia and Tasmania; it grazes and browses at dawn and dusk and shelters in cover during the day.
A Tasmanian form of the red-necked wallaby, adapted to cooler climates and mixed woodland; it feeds on grasses and herbs and is most active in low light.
A small, nocturnal primate of Vietnam, Laos, and Cambodia that feeds on gum, nectar, and insects; it can enter torpor in cooler conditions and is threatened by trade and habitat loss.
A forest-dwelling relative of the giraffe endemic to the Democratic Republic of the Congo; it browses understory leaves and shoots and uses its zebra-like stripes for camouflage in dappled light.
A rare lion subspecies restricted to India, with males typically showing a relatively shorter mane; it is a social apex predator that hunts deer and livestock-sized prey in dry forests and scrub.
Large cat from the Americas, known for powerful build and rosette spots.
